excerpts: Amazingly delicious sesame chicken lunch meal.
It's just so good.
The wait can be up to 15 mins if the place is crowded so I would recommend placing an order a bit in advance over the phone.
Otherwise, no complaints
sesame chicken lunch.author: Tristan S.
sesame chicken lunch.review: Amazingly delicious sesame chicken lunch meal. It's just so good. The wait can be up to 15 mins if the place is crowded so I would recommend placing an order a bit in advance over the phone. Otherwise, no complaints

excerpts: The Special Dinner includes 3 entrees, soup, and rice.
You can also order dumplings for $5.50 instead of $8.95.
The portions are generous.
I ordered a similar meal from Chang's Kitchen on Irving and the portions were puny in comparison.
We enjoyed the freshness and quality of the food.
My only complaint is that the menu on Eat24 didn't specify that the deal comes with rice and soup.
special dinner.author: Katherine S.
special dinner.review: Yummy! Great value and tasty. The Special Dinner includes 3 entrees, soup, and rice. You can also order dumplings for $5.50 instead of $8.95.  The portions are generous. I ordered a similar meal from Chang's Kitchen on Irving and the portions were puny in comparison.  We enjoyed the freshness and quality of the food. My only complaint is that the menu on Eat24 didn't specify that the deal comes with rice and soup.

excerpts: The special dinner deal (to go only) is perfect for being lazy to cook.
Only $20.95, get to pick 3 dishes from selected menu, comes with sour & spicy soup and rice.
special dinner.author: Jen C.
special dinner.review: Good price, large portion, decent food! The special dinner deal (to go only) is perfect for being lazy to cook.  Only $20.95, get to pick 3 dishes from selected menu, comes with sour & spicy soup and rice.  I got the beef with green onion, spicy fish, and eggplant with garlic sauce. It was plentiful for 7 people.  The spicy fish was surprising good.  I was just expecting fillets with chilly sauce over it, but to my surprise, it was deep fried fillets with dried crush pepper and red whole chilly peppers.  It was delicious!  Other food are ok, dumplings are fresh, green onion cake is flavorful.  Potstickers and noodles are just so so.  Overall, very good price for decent food.  However, food are served pretty slow.

excerpts:
Picks:
Green Onion Pancake ($6.50) much more expensive than usual, but thicker and more substantial.
green onion pancake.author: Ellen H.
green onion pancake.review:
A family run Chinese restaurant in the San Francisco Sunset Noriega Street area.  Specializes in dumpling. (No duh?)
Their menu is big and crosses many genres, not a good sign.

 Picks:
Green Onion Pancake ($6.50) much more expensive than usual, but thicker and more substantial.  Could use more flavor.

Shanghai Rice Cakes ($7.95) were decent with good sized rice cakes and nice shredded pork.

Sauteed String Beans ($8.25) were cooked with lots of onions.  Unusual but a decent version.

Frozen Xiao Long Bao Soup Dumplings are sold here. ($8.95 for 10) We ordered some to try later.

Just OK:
Cumin Lamb ($11.55) was reasonable but not great.  A bit greasy and low on heat and flavor.

Would not reorder:
None

Overall - Good
Food - Good
Decor - Good
Service - Good
Value - Good

Would we come back - Maybe

excerpts:
$5.55 

Green onion pancake = good but more doughy than we'd like it.
green onion pancake.author: Fannie S.
green onion pancake.review:
Shredded beef roll =  Thinly sliced beef with equally thinly sliced cucumber in a pancake, which was delicious. $7.95

Shredded potato spicy = If you're expecting the hot-and-sour potatoes...this isn't it but this is equally as delicious with numbing spiciness. $5.55 

Green onion pancake = good but more doughy than we'd like it. $5.95

Fennel pork dumplings (opted for steamed) = good and juicy. 12 pieces for $8.45

Chive and chicken dumplings (pan fried) = excellent and juicy. 12 pieces for $7.95 (I ordered napa cabbage with chicken but they served us this instead.) 

Wonton spicy oil = plenty to share and spicy with a mustard kick. $6.95

Salt and pepper chicken wings = hot, salty, peppery and hit the spot. 8 pieces for $7.95

Vegetable Shanghai noodles = perfect thick cut noodles with crunchy vegetables. $7.55

Mushu Pork = cabbage, wood ear mushrooms, carrots, onions, scallions and julienned pork with pancakes.  $8.95

Service = friendly and polite. 

Noise = loud. Perhaps it was because we were seated near the kitchen but they were banging stuff around.  

Prices = reasonable. Late lunch/early dinner for 5 came out to $73.13, with leftovers.

excerpts: The only 2 complaints were the green onion pancake: some pieces had way too much green onions and other pieces had just specks of green onions; Salt & pepper chicken wings should be renamed to Salty chicken wings.
green onion pancake.author: Florence S.
green onion pancake.review:
Good food, terrible service. 

Actually, I should say service was non-existent. Their waitresses must be paid to focus on packing take out & delivery orders ONLY, because that's all the 3 of them did. And when they were finally away from the counter, they walked around the restaurant with their eyes to the ground. It felt like we needed to use red flares to flag someone down. And it wasn't even busy! We came for a late dinner at 8pm Mother's Day eve. We had a total of 9 dishes but unfortunately I don't remember them all because we were all focused on the overwhelming lack of service. 

The XLB was delicious. There was a lot of broth inside, and the size is great for the price. Also loved their Shanghai Thick Noodles. The only 2 complaints were the green onion pancake: some pieces had way too much green onions and other pieces had just specks of green onions; Salt & pepper chicken wings should be renamed to Salty chicken wings. While the wings were crisp on the outside and juicy on the inside, the amount of salt was overpowering, and there was no zing from any peppers. 

Price was very reasonable. $82 for 9 dishes. The food is good, but unfortunately I don't think I will be back again after this second time. I'd rather pay delivery & tip the driver than tip the wait staff here. Now I see why they get so many take-out and delivery orders.

excerpts: -- GREEN ONION PANCAKE...

$4.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#hqTKQ18DOMPJXD0N6zHPpw)
It was thicker than I typically prefer (thin and crispy), but the outside had a nice crust.
green onion pancake.author: Mike L.
green onion pancake.review:
After reading some of these negative reviews, I think Susy C.'s review is spot on - those people just came in with the wrong expectations.  Although they do offer a few dishes from other Chinese cuisines, China North Dumpling (as its name suggests) focuses mainly on Northern Chinese dishes.  What does that entail, exactly?  Noodles and dumplings galore!

While it may be disappointing for some not to see a favorite like Xiao Long Baos on the menu, China North has plenty of other great dishes to offer - about 160+ in total?  It's impressive that they can offer such an extensive range of appetizers, cold dishes, noodles, vegetable/tofu dishes, soups, seafood, and, of course, numerous types of dumplings (other than XLB).

-- GREEN ONION PANCAKE...$4.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#hqTKQ18DOMPJXD0N6zHPpw)
It was thicker than I typically prefer (thin and crispy), but the outside had a nice crust.  The center was pretty good too, as it was slightly chewy and not bready, and the fresh green onions helped to add a lot of great flavor.

-- NAPA CABBAGE WITH PORK DUMPLING...$6.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#4yE81GGRooZiWYQGK_gaFg)
Although they weren't as tasty as others I've tried (still good), it was awesome how they were so packed with filling.  I wonder if the ones with mushroom or chives would have been better, but these were still solid overall.

-- PAN FRIED DUMPLING...$6.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#kpMtuyZ3pdrTKGisPAFoEw)
Like with the dumplings, every one of these was loaded.  In this case though, the filling was both savorier and juicier.  The bottom crust was the highlight though - the skin had the perfect consistency and the bottom was so nicely browned!

-- SHANGHAI STYLE CHOW MEIN (with Hand Made Noodles)...$7.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#egMPX5J2nxWtfAjLDl3R1w)
Even though they aren't very long (perfect for kids though), the hand made noodles are a plus.  They had just slight bite to them, and the sauce on the noodles was terrific.  A little more meat would have been nice, but it was just fine otherwise.

-- HOUSE SPECIAL PORK...$8.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#e6PEnwsgThYMy4kZcdF8Tw)
While all of the other dishes were good, this one stood out the most.  It was simple (pork belly, bok choy, and their house sauce), but well done.  The bits of pork were cooked perfectly (soft and tender) and I thought the sauce added a slight tartness to the dish.

Considering the three of us were able to try five things for a measly $40 (with leftovers), it's safe to say the portions at China North are both plentiful and cheap.  Which is a good thing too since between the various types of hand pulled noodle soups (particularly the spicy beef noodle soup) and all of the dumplings, there's plenty more to try!  About 155 or so, give or take.

excerpts: Green Onion Pancake:
Blah - All dough and definitely lacked flavor.
green onion pancake.author: Richard H.
green onion pancake.review:
"Terrible service, foreign object in the kimchee and blah tasteless food"

I came here for dinner with family for the first time based on several folks saying how great this place was coupled with the fact that they were recently written up in the San Francisco Chronicle.

Unfortunately, the stars started to drop after we were seated. Arriving at 5:45 pm, the place was empty as it was on the early side for dinner and only three tables were occupied including ours. There were several servers with one hand preparing the pot stickers  two tables away from us. I literally had to do jumping jacks to get someone's attention letting them know we were ready to order.

With that being said and our order placed, our server came back with a small ramekin of salted peanuts and their Chinese version of kimchee which were complimentary. Unfortunately, upon closer inspection as my wife was getting ready to grab a piece of the napa cabbage used in the kimchee a single strand of course black hair was standing up like a lone weed in the ground!  YUCK....Of course we brought it to our server's attention and she emphatically said "sorry."

Dishes that we ordered:

Spicy Beef Noodle Soup:  We all agreed this was the best dishes and the portion was big enough for four people. Noodles and beef were tasty as well as the spice (which was not as spicy as I thought it would be).

Green Onion Pancake: Blah - All dough and definitely lacked flavor. We had to dip it in the Spicy Beef Tendon dish juices in order to eat it.  We had four pieces remaining after we paid the bill. Kitchen needs to add more green onion in their pancakes or have a special dipping sauce to accompany this dish.

Spicy Beef Tendon Cold Platter: I have had better that my brother in law has made. It was probably the second best dish

Crispy Salt and Pepper Chicken:  Just so so. Didn't really stand out in my opinion. Kirin in the Richmond District is so much better. This dish just lacked flavor although the whole pieces of red chili were nice.

Pan Fried Pork and cabbage dumplings: Like many of the yelpsters - I have had better. Very disappointed in this dish as this is what this place is known for.

Shanghai Noodles with Pork: Okay - Yes , the noodles are hand made but again this dish did not stand out. The Napa cabbage mixed with this dish gave it a limp presentation wise and they could have chosen a more heartier green vegetable to make the presentation nicer.

In summary, I doubt that I will be coming back here again. On a separate note. We left after 1.5 hours only to find a line at the door. I still can't figure that one out but perhaps it the reasonable prices.

excerpts: I didn't order the green onion pancake, which I usually love because my friend said it was all dough and no flavor.
I saw another table order this and that's what it looked like.
Skip on the beef pancake rolls.
green onion pancake.author: Karen H.
green onion pancake.review:
3 1/2 Stars. 

I didn't order the green onion pancake, which I usually love because my friend said it was all dough and no flavor. I saw another table order this and that's what it looked like. Darn

The XLB is only ok. Had good flavor, but the skin wasn't that great. 

Skip on the beef pancake rolls. 

The things I would come back for:

-Pork and corn dumplings-juicy and flavorful
-Spicy fried chicken-little pieces of fried chicken. The more you eat, the spicier it gets. This is addicting. 
-Shanghai Noodles-thumbs up
-Bean curd with cucumber-refreshing and good flavors to cleanse your taste buds
-The special fried tofu with meat and bell peppers. Takes awhile, but this is super good. My favorite dish of the night

excerpts: Me and my friend came in for lunch one day and ordered pan fried pork dumplings, spicy beef noodle soup, pork noodle soup, and a green onion pancake.
This place also makes a good amount of "jianbing" - 煎饼 too.
So a good place in the neighborhood if you're in for dumpling .
green onion pancake.author: Alex C.
green onion pancake.review: If it's dumpling in the Parkside to Sunset neighborhood in SF there is one place so farthest been consistent and hasn't failed as many dumpling places have come and gone. China North has somehow survived and thrived and I'm glad e have places that Chinese folk just go, grub eat and casually head home. Like your neighborhood dumpling spot China North offers a good array of hand made dumplings, hand made noodles, and various northern Chinese dishes. Me and my friend came in for lunch one day and ordered pan fried pork dumplings, spicy beef noodle soup, pork noodle soup, and a green onion pancake. This place also makes a good amount of "jianbing" - 煎饼 too. So a good place in the neighborhood if you're in for dumpling .

excerpts: My family ordered the lamb with cumin, the green onion pancake, the dumplings, hot sour soup, spicy beef soup, liver with spicy chilis, and the beef tendon with cucumbers and spicy oil.
It was flavorful and definitely hit it off the spot.
After reading the low reviews and other people's reviews, I definitely agree.
Please do not come to a place like this and expect good fried rice or chow mein.
Go to Panda Express for something like that.
You should primarily get Beijing style food here rather than the typical typical.
green onion pancake.author: Wesley K.
green onion pancake.review: The amount of food for the pricing is pretty decent compared to other Northern Chinese places. My family ordered the lamb with cumin, the green onion pancake, the dumplings, hot sour soup, spicy beef soup, liver with spicy chilis, and the beef tendon with cucumbers and spicy oil. It was flavorful and definitely hit it off the spot. After reading the low reviews and other people's reviews, I definitely agree. Please do not come to a place like this and expect good fried rice or chow mein. Go to Panda Express for something like that. You should primarily get Beijing style food here rather than the typical typical.

excerpts: Next time I think I will just order the green onion pancake.
No more fancy pancakes for me.
green onion pancake.author: Cathy M.
green onion pancake.review:
4 stars only for the dumplings here.  They offer over 10 types of dumplings with a choice of steamed or pan-fried.  Ordered the pan fried  3 flavor vegetarian dumplings which consists of chives, eggs and shrimp.  And steamed Napa cabbage with pork which also has minced ginger inside.  Both kinds were delicious, fresh and juicy. They don't skimp on the filling and the best part was that the skin was not too thick. Comes with a sweet vinegar sauce.  Looking fwd to try the corn and chicken dumplings and the fish one! 

Also ordered the beef noodle soup with their handmade noodles. Yuck. I hate their noodles. Too thick and doughy for me. The soup was bland and the beef was not good. I will pass on this next time. 

The beef pancake roll was OK. I was hoping that the pancake was made with green onion but it was just plain.  Texture was not bad ...thin and slightly crispy.  Next time I think I will just order the green onion pancake.  No more fancy pancakes for me.

excerpts: Got the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup, Wonton in spicy oil, and the green onion pancake as delivery.
Read some past reviews about how the pancake was more of dough and had barely any green onions
so I wasn't expecting anything.
The ones that I got had a decent amount of green onions in them
so I guess it depends per order.
The wontons hit the spot and was sweeter than I expected (then again I eat Shanghai+Taiwan style more often).
Spicy beef noodle soup was more of a meh for me (Too used to San Gabriel Valley and legit Taiwan night market stalls).
Wasn't spicy enough to get my eyes watering and nose runny.
Spicy beef noodle soup was more of a meh for me (Too used to San Gabriel Valley and legit Taiwan night market stalls).
Wasn't spicy enough to get my eyes watering and nose runny.
Beef was slightly overcooked, but the noodles were pretty damn good.
It's hard to find really good beef noodle soup in SF
so I guess this will pass for my tastes.
Overall, I'm pretty satisfied with what I got.
Not sure if I would pay $20+ again for free delivery though.

excerpts:
- Green Onion pancake: large, thick and fluffy = very filling!, unlike the thin fried pancakes commonly found in Shanghai restaurants; had adequate amount of green onions and flavor.  
Chives pancake: 95% minced chives, 5% eggs, I swear there's supposed to be pork in this; flavor is a-ok if you like chives chives chives.
green onion pancake.author: Renee L.
green onion pancake.review:
Came here to try out the new restaurant on the block.  With a name like China North Dumpling, one should hope that dumplings are their specialty but take a look at the menu and you just might realize you were wrong.  

- Green Onion pancake: large, thick and fluffy = very filling!, unlike the thin fried pancakes commonly found in Shanghai restaurants; had adequate amount of green onions and flavor.  
- Chives pancake: 95% minced chives, 5% eggs, I swear there's supposed to be pork in this; flavor is a-ok if you like chives chives chives.  
- Special beef noodle soup: pieces of beef and tendon atop thick noodles in broth; came to our table only a minute after we ordered so I assume this was pre-made and the waitress did tell us that the beef is added on after the noodles are done; noodles by itself were nothing special and I had to add hot sauce to keep from getting bored.  Beef was ok on its own, the tendon was soft and gelatinous the way I like it.  Broth was not bad, maybe a little msg in it?  
- West lake w/ Prawns Fried Dumpling:  What's West Lake, you ask? Oh, just zucchini.  High expectations for this because of its unique ingredients. This was very lightly fried and the dumpling skin seemed fresh and thin.  The interior, however, was disappointing; very little filling (grated zucchini and prawns), bland and soggy, maybe slightly overcooked.  When you cook zucchini, it tends to become a shrunken watery mess if not done right, and this probably contributed to the lack of flavor.  The prawns were diced up to a size smaller than my pinkie fingernail and each dumpling only had maybe 2 of these tiny pieces.  

There was a significant wait time between finishing the first 2-3 dishes and getting our dumplings.  Our clothes also smelled of grease/kitchen odors after we left, I don't usually expect this to happen unless I'm at kbbq.

excerpts: We ordered the Wonton w/ Spicy oil, beef pancake, Chives w/ pork dumpling, and XLB.
The meat in the XLB, dumpling, and pancake was so strong.
Tasted like it was never cleaned.
It was so gross, we didn't finish our food.
pancake.author: Annie Y.
pancake.review:
This has got to be the nastiest dumpling place I've ever been to. First off, the bathroom was stinky and disguising (not because of someone business) but because it needs cleaning. I am so glad we didn't order much. We ordered the Wonton w/ Spicy oil, beef pancake, Chives w/ pork dumpling, and XLB. 

The wonton w/ spicy oil was the best because it was drenched in sauce. The meat in the XLB, dumpling, and pancake was so strong. Tasted like it was never cleaned. It was so gross, we didn't finish our food. The aftertaste linger in our mouth for such a long time even after we drank cups of tea. 

Service: We waited forever to get spoons + our check. NEVER coming back.

excerpts:
We've also been to the actual restaurant and tried their Northern China specialties:
- Beef pancake:
pancake.author: Edna C.
pancake.review:
China North Dumpling is great because 1) they deliver 2) they have family specials. And for the two of us, family special means a hearty meal with leftovers for another hearty meal the next day.

The family special is a good staple for solid Chinese food--you can't go wrong, even though the names of the dishes may sound mundane like "ginger with pork" or the endearingly Engrish name "leaves spareribs". The fish with black bean sauce is my favorite, with a decent amount of fish stir-fried in bold flavors of garlic and black bean. (As a kid I never liked black bean sauce because I thought it looked like bugs, but the boo converted me.)

We've also been to the actual restaurant and tried their Northern China specialties:
- Beef pancake: Tasty, but very small
- Northern style homemade colorful mixed noodles (yes that's the name): Not bad, though I always find this dish to be quite vinegary. Good option if you want to be adventurous.
- Dumpling: Honestly I find dumplings in SF to be all pretty good. (It's the XLB that distinguishes skillz!)

The verdict? Even though the restaurant is called China North Dumpling, I think their Northern Chinese cuisine options are just okay. I am a fan of the family specials of standard Chinese food + delivery (+ Netflix at home!) It's the little things.

-- PAN FRIED DUMPLING...$6.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#kpMtuyZ3pdrTKGisPAFoEw)
Like with the dumplings, every one of these was loaded.  In this case though, the filling was both savorier and juicier.  The bottom crust was the highlight though - the skin had the perfect consistency and the bottom was so nicely browned!

-- SHANGHAI STYLE CHOW MEIN (with Hand Made Noodles)...$7.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#egMPX5J2nxWtfAjLDl3R1w)
Even though they aren't very long (perfect for kids though), the hand made noodles are a plus.  They had just slight bite to them, and the sauce on the noodles was terrific.  A little more meat would have been nice, but it was just fine otherwise.

-- HOUSE SPECIAL PORK...$8.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#e6PEnwsgThYMy4kZcdF8Tw)
While all of the other dishes were good, this one stood out the most.  It was simple (pork belly, bok choy, and their house sauce), but well done.  The bits of pork were cooked perfectly (soft and tender) and I thought the sauce added a slight tartness to the dish.

Considering the three of us were able to try five things for a measly $40 (with leftovers), it's safe to say the portions at China North are both plentiful and cheap.  Which is a good thing too since between the various types of hand pulled noodle soups (particularly the spicy beef noodle soup) and all of the dumplings, there's plenty more to try!  About 155 or so, give or take.

excerpts: We shared an order of the beef pancake wrap.
I was a little disappointed there was no sour cabbage inside of it (that's

it's just what I've grown accustomed to) but happy that there was no cilantro.

pancake.author: Susy C.
pancake.review:
China 101 for some of these low review noobs.

- China North Dumpling is, [obviously] NORTHERN STYLE CHINESE FOOD.
 
- Typical northern Chinese cuisine consists of starchy foods like dumplings,  noodles, buns, and pancakes. If you want a real breakdown, it then varies from northeast to northwest by hand pulled noodles and the buns but I digress.

- Northern China = colder climate which = limited range of food that can grow. As a result = pickled goodies (think garlic, scallions, leeks etc in oil and vinegar) 

- meat consumed is primarily beef and lamb

So for you noobs who order garlic cucumbers and whine about oil, don't come here looking for chow mein or fried rice either.  CHINA NORTH IS NOT SHANGHAINESE. There are NO XLBs here noobs!

Complimentary peanuts and pickled cabbage upon seating. The pickled cabbage is spicy and tasty. 

China North Dumpling does indeed have a variety of dumplings. They offer them steamed or pan fried. My friends and I took so damn long we decided to order the 3 vegetable dumplings [fried] and the mushroom and pork dumplings [steamed]. 
Don't let the 3 vegetable dumplings fool you, it is not vegetarian because there is shrimp. China North only offers vegetarian dumplings on the weekends. 

The dumplings (both steamed and pan fried) were executed beautifully. Generous amounts of filling in the mushroom and pork especially. 

We shared an order of the beef pancake wrap. I was a little disappointed there was no sour cabbage inside of it (that's a-ok w/ me it's just what I've grown accustomed to) but happy that there was no cilantro. The pancake itself looked delicate because it was so thin, but it held up the beef and hoisin sauce that was already inside pretty well. The pancake was crispy. Definitely order this.

I had the spicy beef noodle soup w/ hand made noodles. Oh man. They gave me plenty of beef and there is PLENTY of noodles. The handmade noodles are thick and starchy (duh) and so filling. I LOVE THEM. They are cooked perfectly al dente and the spicy beef noodle soup broth is excellent. A good amount of cumin (totes normal for northern Chinese) and definitely hit the spot. 

I had a few bites of my friend's sesame handmade noodles. This is a cold noodle dish, and served with sliced cucumbers. Very refreshing but also filling because of the hand noodles. It would probably be best to share with another person. 
My other friend had the dumpling noodle soup (also with handmade noodles) which was good and plentiful. The dumplings in his order had minced shrimp in it so I didn't try. 

Total damage was about $50 and we had leftovers. 

I'm coming back to try more dumplings. Definitely don't shy away from the handmade noodles. The noodles and dumplings are made fresh here. I mean let's be real, you're not going to go to HOPR and order the fish right? Well don't be a feckin noob here either.

pancake.author: Candice H.
pancake.review:
Meh...

This place has been open for about a month or so. I had a craving for dumplings so we decided to try China North Dumpling.  You would think dumplings are their specialty given the name of the restaurant.  Boy, were we fooled!

As we walked in, I already smelled the grease odor.  It was probably a sign to go elsewhere, but we decided to give the restaurant a try.


We ordered:

-Garlic Cucumbers:  Cucumbers are supposed to be healthy, right?  Well, you'll be in for a surprise if you order the garlic cucumbers here! As stated in my tip, the "sliced cucumber" had an exuberant amount of oil that gathered at the bottom of the dish.  It was so GROSS!  

-Pork Dumplings: Bland and tasteless

-Green Onion Pancake:  Thick and doughy!  There was no green onion taste!

-Chicken Chow Mein:  I took a bite and had to spit it out!  It was sweet!  When did chicken chow mein become a sweet dish?  We informed our waitress who then took it back to the kitchen.  I guess the cook accidentally grabbed the sugar instead of the salt.  The dish was remade and tasted like what chicken chow mein should taste like. However, it was way too oily.

For a restaurant that wasn't busy, there was a significant wait time between finishing the first 2 dishes and getting our chicken chow mein.  When we left, our clothes and hair wreaked of grease.  Needless to say, I WILL NOT return.

Note to the owner if you're reading this:  please fix the ventilation in your restaurant!

pancake.author: Richard H.
pancake.review:
"Terrible service, foreign object in the kimchee and blah tasteless food"

I came here for dinner with family for the first time based on several folks saying how great this place was coupled with the fact that they were recently written up in the San Francisco Chronicle.

Unfortunately, the stars started to drop after we were seated. Arriving at 5:45 pm, the place was empty as it was on the early side for dinner and only three tables were occupied including ours. There were several servers with one hand preparing the pot stickers  two tables away from us. I literally had to do jumping jacks to get someone's attention letting them know we were ready to order.

With that being said and our order placed, our server came back with a small ramekin of salted peanuts and their Chinese version of kimchee which were complimentary. Unfortunately, upon closer inspection as my wife was getting ready to grab a piece of the napa cabbage used in the kimchee a single strand of course black hair was standing up like a lone weed in the ground!  YUCK....Of course we brought it to our server's attention and she emphatically said "sorry."

Dishes that we ordered:

Spicy Beef Noodle Soup:  We all agreed this was the best dishes and the portion was big enough for four people. Noodles and beef were tasty as well as the spice (which was not as spicy as I thought it would be).

Green Onion Pancake: Blah - All dough and definitely lacked flavor. We had to dip it in the Spicy Beef Tendon dish juices in order to eat it.  We had four pieces remaining after we paid the bill. Kitchen needs to add more green onion in their pancakes or have a special dipping sauce to accompany this dish.

Spicy Beef Tendon Cold Platter: I have had better that my brother in law has made. It was probably the second best dish

Crispy Salt and Pepper Chicken:  Just so so. Didn't really stand out in my opinion. Kirin in the Richmond District is so much better. This dish just lacked flavor although the whole pieces of red chili were nice.

Pan Fried Pork and cabbage dumplings: Like many of the yelpsters - I have had better. Very disappointed in this dish as this is what this place is known for.

Shanghai Noodles with Pork: Okay - Yes , the noodles are hand made but again this dish did not stand out. The Napa cabbage mixed with this dish gave it a limp presentation wise and they could have chosen a more heartier green vegetable to make the presentation nicer.

In summary, I doubt that I will be coming back here again. On a separate note. We left after 1.5 hours only to find a line at the door. I still can't figure that one out but perhaps it the reasonable prices.

pancake.author: Alex C.
pancake.review: If it's dumpling in the Parkside to Sunset neighborhood in SF there is one place so farthest been consistent and hasn't failed as many dumpling places have come and gone. China North has somehow survived and thrived and I'm glad e have places that Chinese folk just go, grub eat and casually head home. Like your neighborhood dumpling spot China North offers a good array of hand made dumplings, hand made noodles, and various northern Chinese dishes. Me and my friend came in for lunch one day and ordered pan fried pork dumplings, spicy beef noodle soup, pork noodle soup, and a green onion pancake. This place also makes a good amount of "jianbing" - 煎饼 too. So a good place in the neighborhood if you're in for dumpling .

excerpts: My family ordered the lamb with cumin, the green onion pancake, the dumplings, hot sour soup, spicy beef soup, liver with spicy chilis, and the beef tendon with cucumbers and spicy oil.

After reading the low reviews and other people's reviews, I definitely agree.
Please do not come to a place like this and expect good fried rice or chow mein.

You should primarily get Beijing style food here rather than the typical typical.

My family ordered the lamb with cumin, the green onion pancake, the dumplings, hot sour soup, spicy beef soup, liver with spicy chilis, and the beef tendon with cucumbers and spicy oil. It was flavorful and definitely hit it off the spot. After reading the low reviews and other people's reviews, I definitely agree. Please do not come to a place like this and expect good fried rice or chow mein. Go to Panda Express for something like that. You should primarily get Beijing style food here rather than the typical typical.

4 stars only for the dumplings here.  They offer over 10 types of dumplings with a choice of steamed or pan-fried.  Ordered the pan fried  3 flavor vegetarian dumplings which consists of chives, eggs and shrimp.  And steamed Napa cabbage with pork which also has minced ginger inside.  Both kinds were delicious, fresh and juicy. They don't skimp on the filling and the best part was that the skin was not too thick. Comes with a sweet vinegar sauce.  Looking fwd to try the corn and chicken dumplings and the fish one! 

Also ordered the beef noodle soup with their handmade noodles. Yuck. I hate their noodles. Too thick and doughy for me. The soup was bland and the beef was not good. I will pass on this next time. 

The beef pancake roll was OK. I was hoping that the pancake was made with green onion but it was just plain.  Texture was not bad ...thin and slightly crispy.  Next time I think I will just order the green onion pancake.  No more fancy pancakes for me.

excerpts:
- Green Onion pancake: large, thick and fluffy = very filling!, unlike the thin fried pancakes commonly found in Shanghai restaurants; had adequate amount of green onions and flavor.  
Chives pancake: 95% minced chives, 5% eggs, I swear there's supposed to be pork in this; flavor is a-ok if you like chives chives chives.
pancake.author: Renee L.
pancake.review:
Came here to try out the new restaurant on the block.  With a name like China North Dumpling, one should hope that dumplings are their specialty but take a look at the menu and you just might realize you were wrong.  

- Green Onion pancake: large, thick and fluffy = very filling!, unlike the thin fried pancakes commonly found in Shanghai restaurants; had adequate amount of green onions and flavor.  
- Chives pancake: 95% minced chives, 5% eggs, I swear there's supposed to be pork in this; flavor is a-ok if you like chives chives chives.  
- Special beef noodle soup: pieces of beef and tendon atop thick noodles in broth; came to our table only a minute after we ordered so I assume this was pre-made and the waitress did tell us that the beef is added on after the noodles are done; noodles by itself were nothing special and I had to add hot sauce to keep from getting bored.  Beef was ok on its own, the tendon was soft and gelatinous the way I like it.  Broth was not bad, maybe a little msg in it?  
- West lake w/ Prawns Fried Dumpling:  What's West Lake, you ask? Oh, just zucchini.  High expectations for this because of its unique ingredients. This was very lightly fried and the dumpling skin seemed fresh and thin.  The interior, however, was disappointing; very little filling (grated zucchini and prawns), bland and soggy, maybe slightly overcooked.  When you cook zucchini, it tends to become a shrunken watery mess if not done right, and this probably contributed to the lack of flavor.  The prawns were diced up to a size smaller than my pinkie fingernail and each dumpling only had maybe 2 of these tiny pieces.  

There was a significant wait time between finishing the first 2-3 dishes and getting our dumplings.  Our clothes also smelled of grease/kitchen odors after we left, I don't usually expect this to happen unless I'm at kbbq.

excerpts: Beef pancake -- a barely there smear of beef, which makes you wonder where all the grease came from.
pancake.author: J M.
pancake.review:
Dumplings seem all the rage these days and here's another one to join the fray.  Unfortunately, it doesn't really add much to the scene.

It's new, it's clean, it's got some strange quirks -- each table has ONE laminated take-out style (folded in 3 parts), the tables are packed very tightly.

Service gets one star right now.  I chalk it up to a slow ramp up from the opening as they figure things out, but right now, it's just glaring even for a Chinese restaurant.  We didn't get a plate of peanuts/pickled veggies like every other table had (although I heard the next table complain their peanuts were not crispy...so maybe I got lucky?).  Never got any tea.  Took three requests to the frantic waitress to get some water.  Asked for bowls to share and didn't get any spoons.  The bowls of course...were dirty.  The table next to us got up and helped themselves to get silverware because they had none even though their food got brought out already (They quipped "I guess it's self-service...")

Food gets two and a half stars.  It's not bad.  It's not great.  But I wouldn't come back.

Beef noodles -- noodles were decent, very few pieces of beef, and the soup was barely flavored.  Overall, edible, but bland.

Vegetarian dumplings -- had filling of eggs and chive.  Again, decent.  Came out really water-logged from the boiling.  Skin is pretty thick and doughy.  Also kinda bland.

Beef pancake -- a barely there smear of beef, which makes you wonder where all the grease came from.  Barely seasoned.

I'll stick to Dumpling Kitchen on Taraval -- it's like night and day.

excerpts: we order, onion pancake, thick and full of nothing but dough.
pancake.author: Guess G.
pancake.review:
Uh ... all I can say is MISS.  

Was in the area so saw the grand opening sign and decided to try, big mistake.  -First item we order, onion pancake, thick and full of nothing but dough.  

-Second, beef noodle soup.  The Soup was BLAND, like almost drinking water and a little msg.  

-Third, we also ordered the Mu Shu Pork (Something we normally don't).  Anyway, the "stuffing" for the wraps came, and it looked like in was baked in soy sauce, totally dark and salty.  Chef poured in way too much soy sauce! They also forgot to bring the wraps for the mu shu pork, so what did one of the waitress do?  She bought UNCOOK egg roll wrappers to give to us for the mu shu pork.  We all gave her the WTF look!?
    
-Our last item, the "Napa Cable with pork dumpling" ..... they bought chives and pork dumpling to us instead.  The dumpling place next door makes better dumpling you can buy to bring home to cook.  

Anyway, the last place that opened up in this spot went belly up not too long.   This isn't going to stay in business very long either with they way it's run and way below par food.

excerpts: Shredded beef roll =
Thinly sliced beef with equally thinly sliced cucumber in a pancake, which was delicious.
shredded beef roll.author: Fannie S.
shredded beef roll.review:
Shredded beef roll =  Thinly sliced beef with equally thinly sliced cucumber in a pancake, which was delicious. $7.95

Shredded potato spicy = If you're expecting the hot-and-sour potatoes...this isn't it but this is equally as delicious with numbing spiciness. $5.55 

Green onion pancake = good but more doughy than we'd like it. $5.95

Fennel pork dumplings (opted for steamed) = good and juicy. 12 pieces for $8.45

Chive and chicken dumplings (pan fried) = excellent and juicy. 12 pieces for $7.95 (I ordered napa cabbage with chicken but they served us this instead.) 

Wonton spicy oil = plenty to share and spicy with a mustard kick. $6.95

Salt and pepper chicken wings = hot, salty, peppery and hit the spot. 8 pieces for $7.95

Vegetable Shanghai noodles = perfect thick cut noodles with crunchy vegetables. $7.55

Mushu Pork = cabbage, wood ear mushrooms, carrots, onions, scallions and julienned pork with pancakes.  $8.95

Service = friendly and polite. 

Noise = loud. Perhaps it was because we were seated near the kitchen but they were banging stuff around.  

Prices = reasonable. Late lunch/early dinner for 5 came out to $73.13, with leftovers.

excerpts: I ordered shredded beef roll, vegetarian dumpling, preserved veg shredded pork noodle soup.
The dumplings are delicious.
Others are just so so.
shredded beef roll.author: Nancy S.
shredded beef roll.review: It is a very traditional Chinese restaurant. It is on the 19th avenue. A friend highly recommended the restaurant. The environment is nice and the waiters are so kind. There are various kinds of food, such as pancakes, noodles, rice and so on. I ordered shredded beef roll, vegetarian dumpling, preserved veg shredded pork noodle soup. The dumplings are delicious. Others are just so so.

excerpts: And the chives pancake I got was too salty with way too much chives but hardly anything else.
To balance it out, I dumped a bunch of chives and put them on the green onion pancakes.
Now that was perfect.
chives pancake.author: Karen L.
chives pancake.review:
Shanghai food so near my house, I wish this place was better.
The green onion pancakes were the thick bready kind, but hardly any onions in it.  The beef noodle soup was pretty bland.  And the chives pancake I got was too salty with way too much chives but hardly anything else.  To balance it out, I dumped a bunch of chives and put them on the green onion pancakes.  Now that was perfect.

excerpts: Chives pancake: 95% minced chives, 5% eggs, I swear there's supposed to be pork in this; flavor is a-ok if you like chives chives chives.
chives pancake.author: Renee L.
chives pancake.review:
Came here to try out the new restaurant on the block.  With a name like China North Dumpling, one should hope that dumplings are their specialty but take a look at the menu and you just might realize you were wrong.  

- Green Onion pancake: large, thick and fluffy = very filling!, unlike the thin fried pancakes commonly found in Shanghai restaurants; had adequate amount of green onions and flavor.  
- Chives pancake: 95% minced chives, 5% eggs, I swear there's supposed to be pork in this; flavor is a-ok if you like chives chives chives.  
- Special beef noodle soup: pieces of beef and tendon atop thick noodles in broth; came to our table only a minute after we ordered so I assume this was pre-made and the waitress did tell us that the beef is added on after the noodles are done; noodles by itself were nothing special and I had to add hot sauce to keep from getting bored.  Beef was ok on its own, the tendon was soft and gelatinous the way I like it.  Broth was not bad, maybe a little msg in it?  
- West lake w/ Prawns Fried Dumpling:  What's West Lake, you ask? Oh, just zucchini.  High expectations for this because of its unique ingredients. This was very lightly fried and the dumpling skin seemed fresh and thin.  The interior, however, was disappointing; very little filling (grated zucchini and prawns), bland and soggy, maybe slightly overcooked.  When you cook zucchini, it tends to become a shrunken watery mess if not done right, and this probably contributed to the lack of flavor.  The prawns were diced up to a size smaller than my pinkie fingernail and each dumpling only had maybe 2 of these tiny pieces.  

There was a significant wait time between finishing the first 2-3 dishes and getting our dumplings.  Our clothes also smelled of grease/kitchen odors after we left, I don't usually expect this to happen unless I'm at kbbq.

excerpts: Wonton with spicy oil (http://bit.ly/2cEKaLO)
These have mustard on the bottom... which really threw me off.
They were the worst wonton with spicy oil I've ever had.
wonton with spicy oil.author: Lily L.
wonton with spicy oil.review:
Was in the neighborhood (unplanned) around lunch time on a Sunday so decided to stop by this place for food. 

Got the green onion pancakes (http://bit.ly/2cDKfw2)
I liked the texture on these and definitely think it was the best dish of the meal. Flavor wise, it's a bit bland. You couldn't really taste the green onions (not that many) and it could have used a bit more salt. I just dipped it in the chili oil at the table (spicier than usual btw) and the sauces from other dishes.

Pork belly with boy choy (http://bit.ly/2d0cgAm)
Got these because I wanted a dish with actual vegetables so just picked one based on the photos in the menu. The sauce was just okay - and that's generally what makes this dish.

Wonton with spicy oil (http://bit.ly/2cEKaLO)
These have mustard on the bottom... which really threw me off. They were the worst wonton with spicy oil I've ever had. Meat kind of bland, mustard with peanut butter was not a great combination, and the sauce was reallly watery. 

The meal I had here was just okay. Definitely didn't have anything that would make me want to come back.

excerpts: Ordered for to go, zucchini lamb dumplings, fried little yellow fish, and soured napa cabbage with lamb soup.
The soup was ok, but they obviously gave me the wrong dumpling which is not acceptable because I'm Muslim and they gave me pork dumpling.
The yellow fish was very thick breaded.
I've had so many fried little yellow fishes in many restaurants, this one is the worst.
Very bad experience overall.
soured napa cabbage with lamb soup.author: Lulu W.
soured napa cabbage with lamb soup.review:
Ordered for to go, zucchini lamb dumplings, fried little yellow fish, and soured napa cabbage with lamb soup.
The soup was ok, but they obviously gave me the wrong dumpling which is not acceptable because I'm Muslim and they gave me pork dumpling. The yellow fish was very thick breaded. I've had so many fried little yellow fishes in many restaurants, this one is the worst. 
Very bad experience overall. =(

excerpts:
Tasty, but very small
- Northern style homemade colorful mixed noodles (yes that's the name): Not bad, though I always find this dish to be quite vinegary.
Good option if you want to be adventurous.
- Dumpling: Honestly I find dumplings in SF to be all pretty good.
northern style homemade colorful mixed.author: Edna C.
northern style homemade colorful mixed.review:
China North Dumpling is great because 1) they deliver 2) they have family specials. And for the two of us, family special means a hearty meal with leftovers for another hearty meal the next day.

The family special is a good staple for solid Chinese food--you can't go wrong, even though the names of the dishes may sound mundane like "ginger with pork" or the endearingly Engrish name "leaves spareribs". The fish with black bean sauce is my favorite, with a decent amount of fish stir-fried in bold flavors of garlic and black bean. (As a kid I never liked black bean sauce because I thought it looked like bugs, but the boo converted me.)

We've also been to the actual restaurant and tried their Northern China specialties:
- Beef pancake: Tasty, but very small
- Northern style homemade colorful mixed noodles (yes that's the name): Not bad, though I always find this dish to be quite vinegary. Good option if you want to be adventurous.
- Dumpling: Honestly I find dumplings in SF to be all pretty good. (It's the XLB that distinguishes skillz!)

The verdict? Even though the restaurant is called China North Dumpling, I think their Northern Chinese cuisine options are just okay. I am a fan of the family specials of standard Chinese food + delivery (+ Netflix at home!) It's the little things.

excerpts: As stated in my tip, the "sliced cucumber" had an exuberant amount of oil that gathered at the bottom of the dish.
sliced cucumber.author: Candice H.
sliced cucumber.review:
Meh...

This place has been open for about a month or so. I had a craving for dumplings so we decided to try China North Dumpling.  You would think dumplings are their specialty given the name of the restaurant.  Boy, were we fooled!

As we walked in, I already smelled the grease odor.  It was probably a sign to go elsewhere, but we decided to give the restaurant a try.


We ordered:

-Garlic Cucumbers:  Cucumbers are supposed to be healthy, right?  Well, you'll be in for a surprise if you order the garlic cucumbers here! As stated in my tip, the "sliced cucumber" had an exuberant amount of oil that gathered at the bottom of the dish.  It was so GROSS!  

-Pork Dumplings: Bland and tasteless

-Green Onion Pancake:  Thick and doughy!  There was no green onion taste!

-Chicken Chow Mein:  I took a bite and had to spit it out!  It was sweet!  When did chicken chow mein become a sweet dish?  We informed our waitress who then took it back to the kitchen.  I guess the cook accidentally grabbed the sugar instead of the salt.  The dish was remade and tasted like what chicken chow mein should taste like. However, it was way too oily.

For a restaurant that wasn't busy, there was a significant wait time between finishing the first 2 dishes and getting our chicken chow mein.  When we left, our clothes and hair wreaked of grease.  Needless to say, I WILL NOT return.

Note to the owner if you're reading this:  please fix the ventilation in your restaurant!

excerpts: Unfortunately don't have good things to say about the pig ears either-
definitely one of the worse ones I've had, and again, I think it's because the sauce they used wasn't the typical red chili sauce.
pig ears.author: Ke C.
pig ears.review:
Another classic sunset district 3 star restaurant. There's something about Chinese food in the sunset district I can't exactly describe, but once you've experienced a few places you'll start noticing it's different in style and taste than Chinese food elsewhere in the city. 

For food, we got the egg flower soup- pretty good, light and with carrots and peas, like ones from a bag in the frozen aisle. Didn't mind them, though.

The braised pork looked dark and deliciously glazed and braised in the menu, but when we received it it fell below expectation. The sauce was brown... not dark like soy sauce. It didn't have the classic soy braised pork taste. The sauce also penetrated the bok choy underneath, making it oily and not super palatable.

Unfortunately don't have good things to say about the pig ears either- definitely one of the worse ones I've had, and again, I think it's because the sauce they used wasn't the typical red chili sauce. The sauce looked paler and tasted more bland.

The dumplings though, they got right. It takes a while to cook, but they're plump, juicy and a big portion of meat filling.

I've been here one other time, and the chicken and mushroom was delicious and tasty but was full of tiny chicken bones. Their beef noodle soup was really not good either, the meat was pretty tough. So all in all, the highlight was... the egg drop soup. Really?! -__-

excerpts: We had to dip it in the Spicy Beef Tendon dish juices in order to eat it.
We had four pieces remaining after we paid the bill.
Spicy Beef Tendon Cold Platter
: I have had better that my brother in law has made.
spicy beef tendon.author: Richard H.
spicy beef tendon.review:
"Terrible service, foreign object in the kimchee and blah tasteless food"

I came here for dinner with family for the first time based on several folks saying how great this place was coupled with the fact that they were recently written up in the San Francisco Chronicle.

Unfortunately, the stars started to drop after we were seated. Arriving at 5:45 pm, the place was empty as it was on the early side for dinner and only three tables were occupied including ours. There were several servers with one hand preparing the pot stickers  two tables away from us. I literally had to do jumping jacks to get someone's attention letting them know we were ready to order.

With that being said and our order placed, our server came back with a small ramekin of salted peanuts and their Chinese version of kimchee which were complimentary. Unfortunately, upon closer inspection as my wife was getting ready to grab a piece of the napa cabbage used in the kimchee a single strand of course black hair was standing up like a lone weed in the ground!  YUCK....Of course we brought it to our server's attention and she emphatically said "sorry."

Dishes that we ordered:

Spicy Beef Noodle Soup:  We all agreed this was the best dishes and the portion was big enough for four people. Noodles and beef were tasty as well as the spice (which was not as spicy as I thought it would be).

Green Onion Pancake: Blah - All dough and definitely lacked flavor. We had to dip it in the Spicy Beef Tendon dish juices in order to eat it.  We had four pieces remaining after we paid the bill. Kitchen needs to add more green onion in their pancakes or have a special dipping sauce to accompany this dish.

Spicy Beef Tendon Cold Platter: I have had better that my brother in law has made. It was probably the second best dish

Crispy Salt and Pepper Chicken:  Just so so. Didn't really stand out in my opinion. Kirin in the Richmond District is so much better. This dish just lacked flavor although the whole pieces of red chili were nice.

Pan Fried Pork and cabbage dumplings: Like many of the yelpsters - I have had better. Very disappointed in this dish as this is what this place is known for.

Shanghai Noodles with Pork: Okay - Yes , the noodles are hand made but again this dish did not stand out. The Napa cabbage mixed with this dish gave it a limp presentation wise and they could have chosen a more heartier green vegetable to make the presentation nicer.

In summary, I doubt that I will be coming back here again. On a separate note. We left after 1.5 hours only to find a line at the door. I still can't figure that one out but perhaps it the reasonable prices.

excerpts: Ordered the beef roll pancake,  pan fried corn and chicken dumpling, steamed pork and cabbage dumplings, spicy beef tendon,  and beef noodles.
Waitress told us the pan fried dumplings would take 20 minutes.
We said ok,  it took over 20 minutes for anything to arrive.
Soup noodles were hand pulled, it was recommended by our waitress.
Soup based very bland, had to tweak it with vinegar and hot sauce.
The beef tendon had lots of garlic to it, only downside is the beef tendon was not tender at all.
It was very chewy.
dumplings were only so-so.
Service spotty, needed more waitress.
Also if they streamlined the kitchen and supplies,  the wait might not be so long.
Not sure if I will come back again.
spicy beef tendon.author: Alicia A.
spicy beef tendon.review: Ordered the beef roll pancake,  pan fried corn and chicken dumpling, steamed pork and cabbage dumplings, spicy beef tendon,  and beef noodles. Waitress told us the pan fried dumplings would take 20 minutes.  We said ok,  it took over 20 minutes for anything to arrive.  Soup noodles were hand pulled, it was recommended by our waitress.  Soup based very bland, had to tweak it with vinegar and hot sauce.  The beef tendon had lots of garlic to it, only downside is the beef tendon was not tender at all. It was very chewy. dumplings were only so-so.  Service spotty, needed more waitress. Also if they streamlined the kitchen and supplies,  the wait might not be so long. Not sure if I will come back again.

excerpts: -- NAPA CABBAGE WITH PORK DUMPLING...
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#4yE81GGRooZiWYQGK_gaFg)
Although they weren't as tasty as others
I've tried (still good)
, it was awesome how they were so packed with filling.
napa cabbage with pork dumpling.author: Mike L.
napa cabbage with pork dumpling.review:
After reading some of these negative reviews, I think Susy C.'s review is spot on - those people just came in with the wrong expectations.  Although they do offer a few dishes from other Chinese cuisines, China North Dumpling (as its name suggests) focuses mainly on Northern Chinese dishes.  What does that entail, exactly?  Noodles and dumplings galore!

While it may be disappointing for some not to see a favorite like Xiao Long Baos on the menu, China North has plenty of other great dishes to offer - about 160+ in total?  It's impressive that they can offer such an extensive range of appetizers, cold dishes, noodles, vegetable/tofu dishes, soups, seafood, and, of course, numerous types of dumplings (other than XLB).

-- GREEN ONION PANCAKE...$4.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#hqTKQ18DOMPJXD0N6zHPpw)
It was thicker than I typically prefer (thin and crispy), but the outside had a nice crust.  The center was pretty good too, as it was slightly chewy and not bready, and the fresh green onions helped to add a lot of great flavor.

-- NAPA CABBAGE WITH PORK DUMPLING...$6.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#4yE81GGRooZiWYQGK_gaFg)
Although they weren't as tasty as others I've tried (still good), it was awesome how they were so packed with filling.  I wonder if the ones with mushroom or chives would have been better, but these were still solid overall.

-- PAN FRIED DUMPLING...$6.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#kpMtuyZ3pdrTKGisPAFoEw)
Like with the dumplings, every one of these was loaded.  In this case though, the filling was both savorier and juicier.  The bottom crust was the highlight though - the skin had the perfect consistency and the bottom was so nicely browned!

-- SHANGHAI STYLE CHOW MEIN (with Hand Made Noodles)...$7.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#egMPX5J2nxWtfAjLDl3R1w)
Even though they aren't very long (perfect for kids though), the hand made noodles are a plus.  They had just slight bite to them, and the sauce on the noodles was terrific.  A little more meat would have been nice, but it was just fine otherwise.

-- HOUSE SPECIAL PORK...$8.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#e6PEnwsgThYMy4kZcdF8Tw)
While all of the other dishes were good, this one stood out the most.  It was simple (pork belly, bok choy, and their house sauce), but well done.  The bits of pork were cooked perfectly (soft and tender) and I thought the sauce added a slight tartness to the dish.

Considering the three of us were able to try five things for a measly $40 (with leftovers), it's safe to say the portions at China North are both plentiful and cheap.  Which is a good thing too since between the various types of hand pulled noodle soups (particularly the spicy beef noodle soup) and all of the dumplings, there's plenty more to try!  About 155 or so, give or take.

excerpts: So, expect dishes like the Szechuan style hot and spicy boiled fish.
Expect hand-pulled noodles (the right amount of chewiness, too!).
hot and spicy boiled.author: Ben T.
hot and spicy boiled.review:
Seriously, I don't know what the hate is about.

Maybe the name is wrong, and therefore people are expecting something different. Expect that there will be spiciness. Expect pickles. Expect oil. Expect mouth-numbing peppercorns. These are staples of the Northern Chinese cuisine. 

So, expect dishes like the Szechuan style hot and spicy boiled fish. Expect hand-pulled noodles (the right amount of chewiness, too!). Expect dumplings.

This was a surprising find in a primarily Cantonese town, but boy do they deliver.

Don't come here on a calorie-watching diet, your brain-computer will explode.

excerpts: The fish with black bean sauce is my favorite, with a decent amount of fish stir-fried in bold flavors of garlic and black bean.
fish with black bean sauce.author: Edna C.
fish with black bean sauce.review:
China North Dumpling is great because 1) they deliver 2) they have family specials. And for the two of us, family special means a hearty meal with leftovers for another hearty meal the next day.

The family special is a good staple for solid Chinese food--you can't go wrong, even though the names of the dishes may sound mundane like "ginger with pork" or the endearingly Engrish name "leaves spareribs". The fish with black bean sauce is my favorite, with a decent amount of fish stir-fried in bold flavors of garlic and black bean. (As a kid I never liked black bean sauce because I thought it looked like bugs, but the boo converted me.)

We've also been to the actual restaurant and tried their Northern China specialties:
- Beef pancake: Tasty, but very small
- Northern style homemade colorful mixed noodles (yes that's the name): Not bad, though I always find this dish to be quite vinegary. Good option if you want to be adventurous.
- Dumpling: Honestly I find dumplings in SF to be all pretty good. (It's the XLB that distinguishes skillz!)

The verdict? Even though the restaurant is called China North Dumpling, I think their Northern Chinese cuisine options are just okay. I am a fan of the family specials of standard Chinese food + delivery (+ Netflix at home!) It's the little things.

excerpts: Our family loves ordering the fried salt and pepper fish, the potstickers and dumplings, the Shanghai noodles, etc.
salt and pepper fish.author: Christine K.
salt and pepper fish.review:
Generous portions and well priced Chinese food.  Our family loves ordering the fried salt and pepper fish, the potstickers and dumplings, the Shanghai noodles, etc.  Definitely mostly hits and I love that they have high chairs, so it makes it very family friendly for those of us with little ones.

I definitely go back and do take-out as well.  Very yummy!

excerpts: Water Spicy Fish is less spicy than I thought, and it's yummy, with a fresh taste of the fish (no idea what kind of fish it is) covered with spicy coat (imagining the spiciness as a rice paper wrapping spring roll with flavors,... here you go), nice balance.
spicy fish.author: Leslie C.
spicy fish.review:
Warning: If you are a fan of Orange Chicken, Broccoli Beef or other Chinese food you think that are real Chinese food, this is not for you.

Visited China North Dumpling with friends at a random afternoon to try some Northern Chinese food. I'm always a fan of Northern Chinese food, however, I can't stand for the heat. Le sigh. 

Dumplings, water boiled or pan-fried? You pick. I like it pan-fried because I can get that crispy warp mixing with the juicy meat melting in my mouth. I love lamb, especially when it cooks with cumin, nothing can beat cumin/lamb combo. I always get this feeling of wide field, grassy, windy in my mind when I have Cumin Lamb. Literally it's like experiencing the wild grass field... with the awesomeness in my mouth. LOVE. Water Spicy Fish is less spicy than I thought, and it's yummy, with a fresh taste of the fish (no idea what kind of fish it is) covered with spicy coat (imagining the spiciness as a rice paper wrapping spring roll with flavors,... here you go), nice balance.

excerpts: My favourite dish is the Spicy Fish.
Its pan fried with chilies - soooo yummy & melts in your mouth.
The flavour is awesome.
It's not on the regular menu, you have to special order it.
They make great Dumplings here of course.
The Shanghai Noodles are great & so filling.
They serve everything with pickled cabbage.
Stick with what they are known for - their staples - such as the dumplings.
The pots of soup and noodle dishes also are quite good.
I tried their food for a take-away and ordered some basic Chinese staples the first time round, cos I was craving Chinese food - and
it was just okay.
I had some Trader Joes dumplings in the freezer
so I didn't order dumplings here
but I did order a soup and
a few a la carte entrees and
they were just average.
But I completely changed my mind after I had the Fish, ordered special dumplings, abd had the Shanghai Noodles!
spicy fish.author: Julian I.
spicy fish.review: My favourite dish is the Spicy Fish. Its pan fried with chilies - soooo yummy & melts in your mouth. The flavour is awesome. It's not on the regular menu, you have to special order it. They make great Dumplings here of course. The Shanghai Noodles are great & so filling. They serve everything with pickled cabbage. Stick with what they are known for - their staples - such as the dumplings. The pots of soup and noodle dishes also are quite good. I tried their food for a take-away and ordered some basic Chinese staples the first time round, cos I was craving Chinese food - and it was just okay. I had some Trader Joes dumplings in the freezer so I didn't order dumplings here but I did order a soup and a few a la carte entrees and they were just average. But I completely changed my mind after I had the Fish, ordered special dumplings, abd had the Shanghai Noodles!

It was plentiful for 7 people.
The spicy fish was surprising good.

It was delicious!
Other food are ok, dumplings are fresh, green onion cake is flavorful.
Potstickers and noodles are just so so.
Overall, very good price for decent food.
However, food are served pretty slow.

spicy fish.review: Good price, large portion, decent food! The special dinner deal (to go only) is perfect for being lazy to cook.  Only $20.95, get to pick 3 dishes from selected menu, comes with sour & spicy soup and rice.  I got the beef with green onion, spicy fish, and eggplant with garlic sauce. It was plentiful for 7 people.  The spicy fish was surprising good.  I was just expecting fillets with chilly sauce over it, but to my surprise, it was deep fried fillets with dried crush pepper and red whole chilly peppers.  It was delicious!  Other food are ok, dumplings are fresh, green onion cake is flavorful.  Potstickers and noodles are just so so.  Overall, very good price for decent food.  However, food are served pretty slow.

excerpts: Ordered for to go, zucchini lamb dumplings, fried little yellow fish, and soured napa cabbage with lamb soup.
The soup was ok, but they obviously gave me the wrong dumpling which is not acceptable because I'm Muslim and they gave me pork dumpling.
The yellow fish was very thick breaded.
I've had so many fried little yellow fishes in many restaurants, this one is the worst.
Very bad experience overall.
fried little yellow fish.author: Lulu W.
fried little yellow fish.review:
Ordered for to go, zucchini lamb dumplings, fried little yellow fish, and soured napa cabbage with lamb soup.
The soup was ok, but they obviously gave me the wrong dumpling which is not acceptable because I'm Muslim and they gave me pork dumpling. The yellow fish was very thick breaded. I've had so many fried little yellow fishes in many restaurants, this one is the worst. 
Very bad experience overall. =(

excerpts: :) we went ham on the menu, and oh my god I am raving about this Szechuan fried chicken, House special pork pancakes and Shanghai chow mein.
The dishes are SOLID and delicious - I am stuffed.
Definitely catch me coming back
house special.author: Grace O.
house special.review: Wow as someone who's been to countless dumpling houses in both SF and China I have to say this place is a gem. Clean interior with friendly staff and nice grandma characters :) we went ham on the menu, and oh my god I am raving about this Szechuan fried chicken, House special pork pancakes and Shanghai chow mein. The dishes are SOLID and delicious - I am stuffed. Definitely catch me coming back

excerpts: -- HOUSE SPECIAL PORK...
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#e6PEnwsgThYMy4kZcdF8Tw)
While all of the other dishes were good, this one stood out the most.
It was simple (pork belly, bok choy, and their house sauce), but well done.
house special.author: Mike L.
house special.review:
After reading some of these negative reviews, I think Susy C.'s review is spot on - those people just came in with the wrong expectations.  Although they do offer a few dishes from other Chinese cuisines, China North Dumpling (as its name suggests) focuses mainly on Northern Chinese dishes.  What does that entail, exactly?  Noodles and dumplings galore!

While it may be disappointing for some not to see a favorite like Xiao Long Baos on the menu, China North has plenty of other great dishes to offer - about 160+ in total?  It's impressive that they can offer such an extensive range of appetizers, cold dishes, noodles, vegetable/tofu dishes, soups, seafood, and, of course, numerous types of dumplings (other than XLB).

-- GREEN ONION PANCAKE...$4.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#hqTKQ18DOMPJXD0N6zHPpw)
It was thicker than I typically prefer (thin and crispy), but the outside had a nice crust.  The center was pretty good too, as it was slightly chewy and not bready, and the fresh green onions helped to add a lot of great flavor.

-- NAPA CABBAGE WITH PORK DUMPLING...$6.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#4yE81GGRooZiWYQGK_gaFg)
Although they weren't as tasty as others I've tried (still good), it was awesome how they were so packed with filling.  I wonder if the ones with mushroom or chives would have been better, but these were still solid overall.

-- PAN FRIED DUMPLING...$6.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#kpMtuyZ3pdrTKGisPAFoEw)
Like with the dumplings, every one of these was loaded.  In this case though, the filling was both savorier and juicier.  The bottom crust was the highlight though - the skin had the perfect consistency and the bottom was so nicely browned!

-- SHANGHAI STYLE CHOW MEIN (with Hand Made Noodles)...$7.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#egMPX5J2nxWtfAjLDl3R1w)
Even though they aren't very long (perfect for kids though), the hand made noodles are a plus.  They had just slight bite to them, and the sauce on the noodles was terrific.  A little more meat would have been nice, but it was just fine otherwise.

-- HOUSE SPECIAL PORK...$8.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/china-north-dumpling-san-francisco?select=1g75lAzSyjmMm7P2jSh3bg#e6PEnwsgThYMy4kZcdF8Tw)
While all of the other dishes were good, this one stood out the most.  It was simple (pork belly, bok choy, and their house sauce), but well done.  The bits of pork were cooked perfectly (soft and tender) and I thought the sauce added a slight tartness to the dish.

Considering the three of us were able to try five things for a measly $40 (with leftovers), it's safe to say the portions at China North are both plentiful and cheap.  Which is a good thing too since between the various types of hand pulled noodle soups (particularly the spicy beef noodle soup) and all of the dumplings, there's plenty more to try!  About 155 or so, give or take.

excerpts: I went back last night and found my new favourite...the House special meatballs.
The texture is unbeatable and having had to try to make this dish myself at home, I know that this kind of texture is time consuming and difficult to execute.
These were perfect.
house special.author: Clarissa S.
house special.review:
I went back last night and found my new favourite...the House special meatballs. The texture is unbeatable and having had to try to make this dish myself at home, I know that this kind of texture is time consuming and difficult to execute. These were perfect. The meatballs were juicy, soft, and not greasy at all and the baby bok choy that is often an afterthought was tenderly prepared and extremely flavourful. 

Don't forget the spicy wontons on the side as well. Insanely good! 

You know what else is awesome though? We came in relatively late-ish expecting to just get things to go, but Jophie (sp?) the sole hostess/server/runner extraordinaire in charge of the restaurant was super kind and accommodating and let us stay and eat way beyond closing time. Definitely a class act and makes me happy to keep patronizing the place.

Can't wait to try more from the menu and keep reporting back!

excerpts: I ordered the shanghai style chow mein, pan fried baos, spicy beef noodles and their house special pork.
Their chow mein with fresh hand pulled noodles was awesome, good flavor and just the right amount of chew in their noodles.
I was disappointed in the baos and the spicy noodles.
The flavor of the baos was a bit unusual from what I thought and the dough was a little on the heavier side.
The spicy noodles was very greasy with chili oil!
Their pork was good but nothing too special.
Overall it was ok
and I would probably order for delivery again on a lazy day.
house special.author: Julie C.
house special.review: I was a bit lazy to cook yesterday and ordered for delivery. I ordered the shanghai style chow mein, pan fried baos, spicy beef noodles and their house special pork. Their chow mein with fresh hand pulled noodles was awesome, good flavor and just the right amount of chew in their noodles. I was disappointed in the baos and the spicy noodles. The flavor of the baos was a bit unusual from what I thought and the dough was a little on the heavier side. The spicy noodles was very greasy with chili oil! Their pork was good but nothing too special. Overall it was ok and I would probably order for delivery again on a lazy day.

excerpts: We had the fish filet with silky tofu, corn with pork dumplling, vegetable Shanghai chow mein and house special meat balls.
The meat balls were huge.
I enjoyed the fish filet with silky tofu the most out of the four items.
Food here is above average to me.
house special.author: Steve T.
house special.review: We got here for lunch at 11 A.M. They were opened several minutes before business hour.  The service was good and fast.  We had the fish filet with silky tofu, corn with pork dumplling, vegetable Shanghai chow mein and house special meat balls.  The meat balls were huge.  I enjoyed the fish filet with silky tofu the most out of the four items.  Food here is above average to me.

excerpts: Their Chicken w. House Special Brown Sauce also used good, fresh ingredients.
Good spicy flavor with a bit of Sichuan Pepper.
A touch too much oil, but still very good.
house special.author: Art Y.
house special.review:
Very fresh dumplings. The chef is from the Shandong area in China. Their name is translated "water dumpling" For those less knowledgeable, their specialty would NOT be XLB, which is a Shanghainese dish. 
The Mushroom with Pork Steam Dumpling was very fresh, had a good amount of quality filling and a good skin. The garlic sweet vinegar gave the correct "ethnic" touch to the dumplings. You can request black/Chinkiang vinegar, but not surprisingly, their garlic vinegar was the better match. The black vinegar imparted too much of its own flavor and "unbalanced" the dish. An excellent selection!
Their Chicken w. House Special Brown Sauce also used good, fresh ingredients. Good spicy flavor with a bit of Sichuan Pepper. A touch too much oil, but still very good.
The more pedestrian MuShu Chicken (in this case) had good ingredients, did not flood the plate or wrappers with a ton of liquid, and was not over salted. The wrappers were the correct, very thin Popiah variety. A good choice, even though it is not a dish from their region.
The Green Onion Pancakes were not great. We saw them making them fresh there, but they were just not light enough. Good if you wanted a heavy dish, but sadly, not a good example of what they should be.

Service was ok. Friendly but understaffed at first, but as more wait staff materialized, it was pretty responsive. In summary, I absolutely would go back. Good quality, unigue dishes with an enthusiastic and polite manager.

excerpts: is their braised eggplant.
I always take people here to try this and they're always surprised that what they're eating is eggplant!
Even non eggplant-fans may like this
and it's always a favorite among our vegetarian friends.
braised eggplant.author: Tiffany H.
braised eggplant.review:
I'm a bit surprised by some of the reviews here but I guess it's a classic case of Order The Right Things. As the name of the restaurant would suggest, order dumplings. But do NOT get the xlb (that's a Shanghai/HK staple, not a Northern Chinese specialty).

Do get the jiaozi, a whole list of which can be found on the first page of their menu. They are able to make most of the jiaozi boiled or pan fried. My personal preference has always been shuijiao over guotie; my favorites here are the pork & cabbage and the shrimp & chives (the classics, baby!). I love that they serve black vinegar instead of soy sauce because that really is the superior way to enjoy dumplings :)

The noodles here are hand pulled and I am a huge fan of their beef noodle soup. I think it may be my second favorite in the entire Bay Area thus far (there's a couple places near Parkside I may have to try first though). 

Their best non-dumpling dish, however, is probably is their braised eggplant. I always take people here to try this and they're always surprised that what they're eating is eggplant! Even non eggplant-fans may like this and it's always a favorite among our vegetarian friends. There's no words to describe the texture or flavor--except that it's ridiculously delicious!

Maybe my standards are different than most non-Chinese, but I've always found the service here to be good. Not stellar but definitely better than most of your average Chinese restaurants. If you dine-in, you also get unlimited amounts of salted peanuts and kimchi as a free appetizer. I've ordered takeout from here many times as well and never had issues.
